text: Platypuses are one of only five species of egg-laying mammals, called monotremes.
Male platypuses have venomous spurs on their hind legs that cause excruciating pain.
Platypuses close their eyes, ears, and nose underwater, navigating entirely by bill.
The platypus bill has over 40,000 electroreceptors that detect prey's muscle signals.

sources.title: Australian Platypus Conservancy - Bill and Electroreception

text: Platypus fur glows blue-green under UV light. This was discovered in 2020.
Platypuses have no stomach. Food goes directly from the esophagus to the intestine.

sources.title: The Nature Conservancy - The Platypus Is Weirder Than You Imagined

text: Female platypuses nurse their young without nipples, sweating milk through skin pores.
Baby platypuses are called puggles and are the size of a jellybean when they hatch.
The platypus has 10 sex chromosomes, compared to 2 in most mammals.
The platypus stores fat in its beaver-like tail as an energy reserve.
When Europeans first saw a platypus specimen in 1799, they thought it was a hoax.

sources.title: Natural History Museum - The platypus puzzle

text: Platypus venom is powerful enough to kill a dog but is not lethal to humans.
A platypus must eat about 20% of its body weight in food every day.
Platypuses use gravel to grind their food because they have no teeth as adults.
Platypuses store caught prey in cheek pouches and chew it at the surface.
A platypus's body temperature is 32Â°C, five degrees lower than most mammals.
The platypus's waterproof fur traps air for insulation, even in near-freezing water.
Platypus milk contains a unique protein that can fight antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

sources.title: PMC - Antimicrobial protein from platypus milk

text: A platypus can detect a shrimp's tail flick from the electric field it generates.
Front feet of a platypus have extra webbing that retracts on land to expose claws.
The platypus spends about 12 hours a day foraging underwater for food.
Platypuses are only found in the wild in eastern Australia and Tasmania.
Female platypuses lay 1-3 leathery eggs and incubate them for about 10 days.
Platypus sex chromosomes are more similar to birds than to other mammals.
George Shaw, who first described the platypus in 1799, cut the pelt looking for stitches.

sources.title: Natural History Museum - The platypus puzzle

text: The platypus is listed as Near Threatened due to habitat loss and declining numbers.
Platypuses can live over 20 years in the wild, long for a small mammal.
Platypus venom is made from defensin-like proteins produced by the immune system.
